content: There is no one specific inspiration behind the choreography for the ballet Giselle, as it was created by a group of collaborators in the mid-19th century. The ballet was choreographed by Jean Coralli and Jules Perrot, with a score by Adolphe Adam, and it tells the story of a young peasant girl named Giselle who falls in love with a nobleman named Albrecht. However, when she discovers that Albrecht is engaged to another woman, she dies of a broken heart and becomes a ghostly figure known as a Wilis. The choreography for Giselle was influenced by a variety of dance styles, including classical ballet, folk dances, and court dances, and it is known for its romantic and ethereal quality. The ballet has since become a beloved classic of the dance repertoire, inspiring countless adaptations and interpretations over the years.
